name: alpine sea holly
gen info: deadheading
watering: not necessary, only during droughts
soil: moist soil, good drainage, prefers sandy soil, tolerates poor soil conditions and drought,
citation: “Sea Holly Plant Care: How To Grow A Sea Holly Plant,” Gardening Know How. [Online]. Available: https://www.gardeningknowhow.com/ornamental/flowers/sea-holly/sea-holly-flowers.htm. [Accessed: 11-Apr-2019].

name: anthurium
gen info: entire plant is poisonous, ingestion can cause stomac issues, touching can cause skin irritation
how to plant: Anthuriums should be planted in raised beds of 1.3 to 2 meters wide and 20 cm deep. Anthuriums should not be planted more than 5 cm deep, as deep planting results in the rotting of stems and roots. Stake the anthurium after planting for support. Water the anthuriums immediately after planting.
watering: water thoroughly, let slightly dry between waterings, over watering can cause root damagage or yellowing of leaves
sunlight: need high light but not direct sunlight
soil: wide range from sandy loams to heavy clays, need good water retention and drainage
citation: “Anthurium Flower Facts, Growing & Caring Anthuriums Plant,” The Flower Expert. [Online]. Available: https://www.theflowerexpert.com/content/aboutflowers/exoticflowers/anthuriums. [Accessed: 11-Apr-2019].

name: artichoke
gen info: for best flavor, harvest when the buds are still tightly closed. Or you can wait until they bloom for flower arrangements
how to plant: best planted form bare-root stock or divisions.
watering: water heavily
soil: sandy, well-drained soil
citation: “Artichokes: Plant Care and Collection of Varieties,” Artichokes: Plant Care and Collection of Varieties - Garden.org. [Online]. Available: https://garden.org/plants/group/artichokes/. [Accessed: 11-Apr-2019].

soil: well drained

name: ball moss
how to plant: propagate by seed or division of balls
watering: 30min-1hr once a week during active growing season, water sparingly during winter
sunlight: bright filtered light indoors, avoid direct midday sun outdoors
citation: “Plants & Flowers,” Plants & Flowers » Ball Moss. [Online]. Available: http://www.plantsrescue.com/tag/ball-moss/. [Accessed: 11-Apr-2019].

gen info: deer resistent
soil: well drained

name: barbeton daisy
gen info: Native to South Africa this species is a perennial in warmer climates but in cooler countries (temperate regions) it's grown as an annual and flowering pot plant. There are many varieties and hybrids sold that are more compact in growth than the basic type. The basic type has stalks which grow up to 2ft tall that can become quite lanky and unattractive.
how to plant: These are mostly propagated with seeds although the parent plant can also be divided or root cuttings can be used.
watering: keep the soil moist at all times. Once the soil becomes slightly dry to the touch provide water straight away or the plant will begin to wilt very quickly.
soil: A peat based potting mix with 2 parts peat and 1 part perlite is suggested.
citation: “Barberton Daisy - Gerbera Jamesonii - Indoor Care and Description,” House Plants Expert. [Online]. Available: https://www.houseplantsexpert.com/barberton-daisy.html. [Accessed: 11-Apr-2019].

name: bearded iris
gen info:
non-aggressive
non-invasive
not native to North America - Product of horticultural selection
how to plant: Propagate by division or separation - Divide in midsummer. Replant only rhizomes that appear strong and healthy, discard others. Cut the healthy rhizomes into pieces with one foliage fan each, cutting the foliage back to only 6” in height. Allow the cut rhizomes to cure overnight, then replant them in well-worked soil.
watering: Keep moist but not soggy while blooming, then keep the soil very dry after flowering has finished and the foliage has faded. Remove faded foliage and blooms to prevent disease.
soil: well drained, fertile soil
citation: “Iris, Bearded (medium height),” Explore Cornell - Home Gardening - Flower Growing Guides - Growing Guide. [Online]. Available: http://www.gardening.cornell.edu/homegardening/scenefc80.html. [Accessed: 11-Apr-2019].

name: bee balm
gen info: aggressive - Can spread by underground rhizomes. non-invasive native to North America - Native to rich, moist woodlands from Ontario to Georgia and west to Illinois. fragrant - Flowers are lightly scented. Leaves, stems, and roots carry a delicious aromatic orange-like perfume when crushed.
how to plant:
Propagate by seed, cuttings, division or separation - Plant seeds in containers in cold frame. Seeds germinate in 10 to 40 days.

Take basal softwood cuttings with plenty of underground stem in spring. Pot individually and keep in light shade in a cold frame or greenhouse until well rooted, then plant out.

Divide clumps of the spreading root system every 2 or 3 years in early spring before growth begins. Plant the large clumps directly into a sunny moist location. Pot small divisions and grow in light shade in a cold frame until well established before planting out.
watering: Needs continuous moisture in summer, but protection from excessive moisture in winter.
soil: requires damp soil tolerates low fertility.
citation: “Bee balm,” Explore Cornell - Home Gardening - Flower Growing Guides - Growing Guide. [Online]. Available: http://www.gardening.cornell.edu/homegardening/scene13fe.html. [Accessed: 11-Apr-2019].

name: bird of paradise
gen info: There are five Strelitzia species, but only two are grown as indoor plants: Strelitzia reginae (the orange bird of paradise) and Strelitzia nicolai (the white bird of paradise). These plants grow with upright leaves emerging directly from the soil; there is no trunk. The large leaves range between 12 and 18 inches long, and they can shred when exposed to windy conditions or when brushed in a busy hallway.
how to plant: Bird of paradise is easy to propagate by division of the underground rhizome when you repot it. Separate a shoot with at least three leaves. It can be grown from seed, but division is easier. It can take months for the seeds to germinate. Divide infrequently because crowded clumps produce the most blooms.
watering: Keep the soil continually moist throughout the year. You don't want it to be waterlogged, but you can expect to need to water it daily in the spring and summer as it loses moisture through its big leaves. Bird of paradise prefers high humidity and you might want to keep a spray bottle handy to mist it if your home is dry. If overwatered the plant will develop crunchy brown leaves. If underwatered the leaves farthest from the center will turn yellow.
seasons: blooms late winter to early spring
warnings: Monitor the plant for aphids, scale, and mites. Bird of paradise is also susceptible to Botrytis cinerea (gray mold). Flowers and leaves with this condition will develop dark spots and then a layer of gray mold. Remove the affected parts of the plant and give your plant regular airing.
sunlight: full sun, but shielding from midday summer sun
soil: rich, well-drained potting mix.
citation: J. VanZile, “Grow the Beautiful Tropical Bird of Paradise Plant With These Tips,” The Spruce, 17-Jan-2019. [Online]. Available: https://www.thespruce.com/how-to-grow-strelitzia-1902742. [Accessed: 11-Apr-2019].

name: bishop of llandaff
gen info: With its deep purple-black leaves and brilliant summer blooms, ‘Bishop of Llandaff’ is a fine addition to the sunny bed or border. The 4- to 6-inch-round red-petaled flowers have deep purple and yellow centers, which are set off nicely by the plant’s dark foliage. Use this long-stemmed cultivar in cut-flower arrangements.
how to plant: Division in spring is preferred. Use a sharp knife to sever tubers ensuring that each division has at least one eye.
watering: Do not water until growth appears above the ground; once plants are established, a deep watering twice a week will get them through summer dry periods
soil: rich, well-drained soil
citation: “'Bishop of Llandaff' Dahlia,” FineGardening. [Online]. Available: https://www.finegardening.com/plant/dahlia-dahlia-bishop-llandaff. [Accessed: 11-Apr-2019].   “Dahlia 'Bishop of Llandaff',” White Flower Farm. [Online]. Available: https://www.whiteflowerfarm.com/40884-product.html#!growguide. [Accessed: 11-Apr-2019].

name: blackberry lily
gen info:
on-aggressive
non-invasive
not native to North America - Asia
bears ornamental fruit - The plants bear oval seed pods which open in the fall to reveal a row of berry-like, shiny black seeds.
how to plant:
Propagate by seed, division or separation - Divide in the early spring.

Sow seeds in autumn or spring. Pre-chilling the seeds may aid germination. Self-seeds readily, but unwanted seedlings are easy to remove.

Days to emergence: 21
soil: well drained
citation: “Blackberry Lily,” Explore Cornell - Home Gardening - Flower Growing Guides - Growing Guide. [Online]. Available: http://www.gardening.cornell.edu/homegardening/scenebb97.html. [Accessed: 11-Apr-2019].

name: black-eyed susan
gen info: Black-eyed Susans (Rudbeckia hirta) are native to North America and one of the most popular wildflowers grown. They tend to blanket open fields, often surprising the passerby with their golden-yellow beauty.
how to plant: Sow by seeds. Plant black-eyed Susans when the soil temperature has reached 70°F for best seed germination. In many parts of North America, the planting period is March to May. The flower will flower June to September. Germination takes 7 to 30 days.
watering: Check your plants regularly to see if they need watering. Make sure they don’t dry out.
soil: Plant seeds in moist, well-drained soil.
citation: “Black-eyed Susans,” Old Farmer's Almanac. [Online]. Available: https://www.almanac.com/plant/black-eyed-susans. [Accessed: 11-Apr-2019].

name: blanket flower
gen info: Produced above a clump of hairy, narrow, gray-green leaves, the blossoms of perennial blanket flower have petals that may be solid colored shades of yellow, wine red , orange or peach, or may be banded in combinations of red or orange with yellow. The petals of some are frilled, while others have a unique, tubular shape. Sizes range from 10-12 inch high dwarfs to selections as tall as 24-30 inches. All are easy care plants with few insect or disease problems and most are hardy in zones 3-9.
how to plant: Container grown plants can be set out throughout the growing season, but spring or fall planting is ideal. Space dwarf cultivars about a foot apart; taller varieties should be set about 18 inches apart. Prepare the garden bed by using a garden fork or tiller to loosen the soil to a depth of 12 to 15 inches, then mix in a 2- to 4-inch layer of compost. Dig a hole twice the diameter of the pot the plant is in. Carefully remove the plant from its container and place it in the hole so the top of the root ball is level with the soil surface. Carefully fill in around the root ball and firm the soil gently. Water thoroughly.
watering: Water newly set out or divided plants regularly until they become established.
seasons: blooms early summer to early fall
soil: very well-drained soil, prefer loose, sandy soil that isn't overly fertile with a pH near neutral or slightly alkaline.
citation: “Blanket Flowers: Plant Care and Collection of Varieties,” Blanket Flowers: Plant Care and Collection of Varieties - Garden.org. [Online]. Available: https://garden.org/plants/group/blanketflowers/. [Accessed: 11-Apr-2019].

name: bougainvillea
gen info: The Bougainvillea is an immensely showy, floriferous and hardy plant. Virtually pest-free and disease resistant, it rewards its owner with an abundance of color and vitality when it is well looked after. The bougainvillea’s versatility is legendary. It can be coaxed into a small manageable pot plant or a sizeable tree, to spread itself vertically on a wall, or climb up a trellis and form a luscious crown or burst forth into graceful arches. It makes one of the best hedges, bushes, and curb-liners.
how to plant: Generally, bougainvillea can be grown in anything that will hold soil and allow proper drainage. Some of the more traditionally used containers include terra cotta (clay) pots, plastic pots, hanging baskets, wire baskets lined with sphagnum moss or fibrous liners, concrete planters, planter boxes, and bushel baskets.
seasons: blooms fall to spring (depening on climate)
soil: well-drained soils
citation: “Bougainvillea 101 | Bougainvillea Plant Care & Fertilizer,” BGI Premium Plant Foods, 06-Oct-2017. [Online]. Available: https://www.bgi-usa.com/bougainvillea-101/. [Accessed: 11-Apr-2019].

name: bromelia
watering: Bromeliads are adapted to withstand drought, but are much less tolerant of being over-watered which can cause root rot. It is important that your bromeliad is planted in a medium that allows for fast drainage.  Each time you water the potting medium, thoroughly soak it so that the water runs from the drainage holes
soil: potting mixes specially formulated for bromeliads or mix your own using porous materials.

name: buttercup
gen info: Buttercup flowers are members of the Ranunculus genus, a large family (about 400 species) of flowers. These bright, yellow, five-petaled summer bloomers, are native to Asia, Australia, Central America, North America and Europe.
how to plant: Buttercups grow from seed or roots. The seed is difficult to germinate and takes weeks to sprout. Most people grow these plants from division of the roots.  Divide plants in spring or fall.
watering: Water established plants during dry periods and droughts.
soil: light soil that drains well, prefers rich soil

name: californian poppy
gen info:
deer resistant
non-aggressive
non-invasive
native to North America - North America
how to plant: Propagate by seed - This plant does not transplant well and should be grown from seeds scattered outdoors in the spring when the soil becomes workable. Scatter the seeds where the plants are desired for summer bloom. This plant may seem like it is a perennial, coming back in the same place every year due to self-seeding. However, self-seeding may not produce plants identical to the initial planted variety.
soil:
tolerates droughty soil
requires well-drained soil
requires high fertility
Thrives in dry, sandy areas, and will stand up well to heat.
citation: “California Poppy,” Explore Cornell - Home Gardening - Flower Growing Guides - Growing Guide. [Online]. Available: http://www.gardening.cornell.edu/homegardening/scene43bf-2.html. [Accessed: 11-Apr-2019].

name: canna lily
gen info: non-aggressive non-invasive not native to North America - Product of horticultural selection. Parents native to tropical areas of Asia and the Americas.
how to plant: Propagate by division or separation - Divide the rhizomes when planting after danger of frost has passed in spring. Each segment should have a strong, healthy "eye."
watering: Keep watered but not soggy.
soil: requires well-drained soilPrefer fertile, moist but well-drained soil.
citation: "Canna Lily,” Explore Cornell - Home Gardening - Flower Growing Guides - Growing Guide. [Online]. Available: http://www.gardening.cornell.edu/homegardening/scene0750.html. [Accessed: 11-Apr-2019].

name: canterbury bells
gen info:
non-aggressive
non-invasive
not native to North America - Europe
how to plant: Propagate by seed - Start seeds outdoors in late spring or early summer in a nursery area of the garden. Thin and grow for the summer in the holding area, overwinter, and transplant into the flower garden the following spring.
soil: requires well-drained soil, prefer moist soil and cool weather with low humidity.
citation: "Canterbury Bells,” Explore Cornell - Home Gardening - Flower Growing Guides - Growing Guide. [Online]. Available: http://www.gardening.cornell.edu/homegardening/sceneab8a.html. [Accessed: 11-Apr-2019].

name: columbine
gen info:
deer resistant
aggressive - Self-seeds if not deadheaded.
non-invasive
not native to North America - Product of horticultural selection.
how to plant: Propagate by seed, division or separation - Grow only from purchased, labelled seed, as most hybrids do not come true from home-raised seed. Divide carefully in spring. Plants don't like to be disturbed and may take a long time to recover.
watering: Provide constant moisture in full sun without waterlogging the soil.
soil: requires well-drained soil, prefers rich, moist but well-drained soil.

name: cyclamen
gen info: non-aggressive non-invasive not native to North America - Native to Asia Minor and Southeastern Europe
how to plant: Propagate by seed, division or separation - Soak seeds for 12 hours before planting. Sow the seeds in late spring for next year's flowering. Plant tubers (actually enlarged hypocotyls) in late summer or early fall.
soil: requires well-drained soilPrefers rich, moist but well-drained soil
citation: "Cyclamen, Hardy,” Explore Cornell - Home Gardening - Flower Growing Guides - Growing Guide. [Online]. Available: http://www.gardening.cornell.edu/homegardening/scene5622.html. [Accessed: 11-Apr-2019].

name: daffodil
gen info: deer resistant non-aggressive non-invasive not native to North America - Product of horticultural selection. fragrant - Some cultivars have sweetly scented blooms.
how to plant: Propagate by division or separation - Plants the bulbs 5" deep. Divide after flowering or in the fall.
soil: requires well-drained soilPrefers moist but well-drained soil.

name: foxglove
gen info: deer resistant aggressive - Foxgloves self-seeds prolifically. non-invasive not native to North America - Native to woodland edges in Europe and northern Africa.
how to plant: Propagate by seed - Start seeds outdoors in a nursery bed any time after frost danger has passed up until 2 months before the first heavy fall frost. Do not cover, as light aids germination. Transplant the plants to their garden location in the fall or the following spring. Plants readily self-seed.
sunlight: full sun, partial shade, full shade
soil: requires well-drained soil tolerates damp soil. Tolerates a wide range of soil conditions, except for very wet or very dry. Prefers rich soil that is moist but well-drained
citation: "Foxglove,” Explore Cornell - Home Gardening - Flower Growing Guides - Growing Guide. [Online]. Available: http://www.gardening.cornell.edu/homegardening/scenec1a6.html. [Accessed: 11-Apr-2019].

name: gaura
gen info: non-aggressive non-invasive native to North America - Southern United States
how to plant: Propagate by seed - Sow seeds where desired in the spring. Very easy to grow from seed.
seasons: blooms mid summer to early fall
soil: tolerates droughty soil requires well-drained soil

name: gazania
gen info:
non-aggressive
non-invasive
not native to North America - South Africa
how to plant: Propagate by seed, cuttings - Start the seeds indoors 6 to 8 weeks before the last spring frost date, or scatter the seeds where desired outdoors after frost danger has passed. Cover the seeds lightly, as darkness aids germination. Make basal cuttings in late summer or early fall.
seasons: blooms early summer to early fall
soil: tolerates droughty soil requires well-drained soil tolerates low fertilityPrefers sandy, well drained soil. Performs best in hot weather.
citation: "Gazania,” Explore Cornell - Home Gardening - Flower Growing Guides - Growing Guide. [Online]. Available: http://www.gardening.cornell.edu/homegardening/scene5877.html. [Accessed: 11-Apr-2019].

name: geranium
gen info: deer resistant non-aggressive non-invasive not native to North America - Native to South Africa
how to plant:
Propagate by seed, cuttings - Geraniums can be grown from barerooted plants salvaged from the garden before the first killing frost. Remove the plants from the soil and shake excess soil from their roots. Place them in a cool, dry place where they will not freeze, and keep their roots marginally moist. Wrapping them with slightly moistened peat moss works well. In spring, 6 to 8 weeks before the last frost, cut the plant stems and roots back (roots to about 6” long), soak them overnight in slightly warmed water, and pot them for growth, placing the pots in a sunny location. Water only when new growth appears. Plant outside after frost danger has passed.

Propagate geraniums from stem cuttings taken in late summer to early fall. Some hybrids are patented, so be sure to heed any warnings and follow all laws concerning their propagation.

Geraniums may also be grown from seed, which should be sown indoors 4 months before the last spring frost date.
seasons: blooms late spring to early fall
soil: tolerates droughty soil requires well-drained soilDoes poorly in clay soil. Prefers slightly acid soil. Needs regular watering and fertilization for optimum performance, but will tolerate long dry spells.
citation: "Geranium, Common,” Explore Cornell - Home Gardening - Flower Growing Guides - Growing Guide. [Online]. Available: http://www.gardening.cornell.edu/homegardening/scene5582.html. [Accessed: 11-Apr-2019].

name: globe thistle
gen info:
deer resistant
non-aggressive - May self-seed, but not very aggressively.
non-invasive
not native to North America - Native to Central Asia, South-Central and Southeastern Europe.
bears ornamental fruit - Spherical seedheads are attractive.
how to plant:
Propagate by seed, division or separation - Self-seeds readily. Sow seed in beds in mid-spring.

Do not divide plants until they are at least 3 years old and basal plantlets are visible. Divide in spring. Cut the roots back to about 8” in length.
seasons: blooms mid summer to early fall
soil: tolerates droughty soil requires well-drained soilPerforms well in hot, dry climates.

gen info:
non-aggressive - Spreads rapdly to form clumps, but is manageable.
non-invasive
not native to North America - Native to the Mediterranean
fragrant - Blooms have an attractive grape-like aroma.
how to plant: Propagate by division or separation - Plant the bulbs in fall so that their tops are 2" below the soil surface. Divide the bulbs in the late summer or fall.
soil: requires well-drained soil
citation: "Hyacinth, Armenian Grape,” Explore Cornell - Home Gardening - Flower Growing Guides - Growing Guide. [Online]. Available: http://www.gardening.cornell.edu/homegardening/scene4971.html. [Accessed: 11-Apr-2019].

gen info:
deer resistant
aggressive - Once established, the plants spread to form dense clumps if conditions are right.
non-invasive
not native to North America - Product of horticultural breeding.
how to plant: Propagate by cuttings, division or separation - Take root sections when the plant is dormant and place vertically in loose propagation medium in flats placed in a cold frame. Divide the plant as desired in the spring. Fall division is usually unsuccessful.
watering: Water during summer dry spells. Plants do not tolerate drought well.
seasons: blooms late summer to mid fall
soil: tolerates acid soil requires well-drained soil requires high fertility

name: monkshood
gen info: deer resistant non-aggressive non-invasive not native to North America - China
how to plant:
Propagate by seed, division or separation - Carefully prepare soil before planting, adding lots of organic matter. Plan where you want Monkshood carefully, because plants don't like to be transplanted and are slow to establish. (The roots are brittle.) Plant roots or divide plants in fall or spring. 
Sow seed outdoors in fall, early winter or early spring. Seed is slow to germinate, sometimes taking 1 to 2 years.
seasons: blooms later summer to early fall
soil: requires well-drained soilPrefers soil that is kept moist but not soggy.
citation: "Monkshood,” Explore Cornell - Home Gardening - Flower Growing Guides - Growing Guide. [Online]. Available: http://www.gardening.cornell.edu/homegardening/scene8d7a.html. [Accessed: 11-Apr-2019].

native to North America - North America
how to plant: Propagate by seed - Start seeds indoors 4 to 6 weeks before the last spring frost, or outdoors where desired after frost danger has passed. Before planting, nick the hard-coated seeds with a file or soak overnight in warm water.
soil: requires well-drained soil

non-aggressive - Plants spread to form large clumps, but are not usually a nuisance.
non-invasive
not native to North America - Products of horticultural breeding
fragrant - Blooms are sweetly fragrant.
naturalistic garden
how to plant:
Propagate by devision or separation - divide in early fall

Plant the corms 2" below the surface of the ground.
When forcing these bulbs, do not move them into a warm location until the flower buds show some color. Moving them earlier may result in failure to flower.

name: toad lily
gen info: grown in residencial gardens, likes shade and hotter areas
watering: perform best in rich, moist, well-drained soil. while it can handle short droughts, it needs to be watered soon after
soil: consistently moist, best in humusy, organic soil that can't dry out. don't keep the soil soggy

name: tree mallow
gen info: blooms for a long time
how to plant: choose a sunny and wind-protected spot. Keep a planting distance of 32 inches (80 cm) to 3 feet (1 meter) between tree mallow plants in order for them to have the space they need to develop well.
watering: doesnt require a lot of water but water regularly so the roots can develop
warnings: disease - rust, brown or tan blisters under the leaves and yellow spots on the top
soil: ordinary, in the summer water as soon as dry, add flower plant fertilizer
citation: “Tree mallow - planting, pruning and advice on caring for it,” Nature, 05-Sep-2018. [Online]. Available: https://www.nature-and-garden.com/gardening/tree-mallows-care-planting-watering.html. [Accessed: 11-Apr-2019].

name: tree poppy
gen info: drought tolerant, bright yellow flowers, can grow to 20 feet tall
how to plant:
plant in fall or early winter
Measure an area 20 feet by 20 feet for the plant to occupy. Dig a planting hole twice as deep and three times as wide as the container the tree poppy is growing in.
let the top of the root be at the top of the hole. backfill beneath and to the sides of the roots, removing air gaps. use excess soil to make a watering basin around the planting hole. Mound up a rim of soil that encloses the entire planting hole. Tamp the soil berm firmly in place so water won't leak out. Water the plant thoroughly.
watering: water occasionally through hot/dry months for the first two years to establish root system. less frequent after, deep watering and don't over water
warnings:
do not fertilize
prune and remove dead parts. don't prune older plants heavily. withdraw watering as poppy becomes established.
soil:
amend soil with decomposed granite, pumice or perlite to create good drainage
put in areas around the planting hole as well
citation: C. Chaney, “How to Take Care of Dendromecon Tree Poppies,” Home Guides | SF Gate, 07-Oct-2016. [Online]. Available: https://homeguides.sfgate.com/care-dendromecon-tree-poppies-28566.html. [Accessed: 11-Apr-2019].

name: trumpet creeper
gen info: pollinated by hummingbirds and long tongued bees
how to plant: stratify 30-60 days at 41-50 degrees for seeds
watering:
To keep lush during droughts, water deeply on occasion. Mow to keep it from expanding beyond defined areas. Cut back branches to two buds in the winter to encourage bushier growth and more blooms.
low
warnings: the sap can cause skin irritaiton on contact
soil:
Various well-drained soils. Sandy, Sandy Loam, Medium Loam, Clay Loam, Clay, Limestone-based, Caliche type
dry moist
citation: “Plant Database,” Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center - The University of Texas at Austin. [Online]. Available: https://www.wildflower.org/plants/result.php?id_plant=cara2. [Accessed: 11-Apr-2019].

name: wallflower
lifecycle: can be annuals, biennials, or perennials
sunlight: grown in full sun, but will tolerate light or dappled shade
citation: “Wallflowers,” Love The Garden. [Online]. Available: https://www.lovethegarden.com/plant-finder/annuals/wallflowers. [Accessed: 11-Apr-2019].

name: watercress
gen info: grows partially submerged in running water and flooded areas in cool climates
how to plant: In the garden proper, you can dig out a 6-inch furrow, line it with 4-6 mil polyethylene and then fill with 2 inches of composted soil or peat moss. Of course, if you have a running stream on your property, watercress cultivation is about as simple as it gets.
watering: Watercress can also be grown in consistently wet soil with a soil pH of 6.5-7.5 in full sun, or you can mimic natural conditions by growing watercress plants in a bucket or other container.
seasons: flavor is best during cool months, once blossomed, the flavor is compromised
sunlight: light shade, will grow in sunny position if soil is kept wet
soil: keep soil wet/perminently damp soil
citation: “Care Of Watercress: Growing Watercress Plants In Gardens,” Gardening Know How. [Online]. Available: https://www.gardeningknowhow.com/edible/herbs/watercress/growing-watercress-in-gardens.htm. [Accessed: 11-Apr-2019].

name: water lily
gen info:
Water lily is a plant native to Europe and North America
It is also possible to grow water lily in pots, large water drums or garden boxes that don’t let water drain on a terrace or balcony.
Indeed, it is a very hardy and resilient plant, and stress is perhaps the only factor that can endanger your water lily.
how to plant:
plant in the spring - at the bottom of a body of water
6 inches (15 cm) of water are enough for most species, although some may require a greater depth.
put some heavy clay soil in a pot/tray to keep plant at the bottom, plant the water lily in it.
Spread rocks over the soil to keep it from floating back up.
Once your basket is ready, immerse it in water. Ideally, let it rest about 24 inches (60 cm) deep.
Once properly settled in, your water lily won’t need any follow-up and will simply bloom year after year without even needing to touch it.

There exist special baskets at horticulture stores, they help water circulate well without letting the soil disperse throughout the water basin.There are even specific soil mix preparations for aquatic plants.
watering:
needs small body of water
no need to water! Simply check that there is always enough water in the pond, minimum about 4 inches (10 cm).
warnings: Apart from ducks and the occasional muskrat that sometimes eat the rhizomes, only very few diseases have been seen to deplete the plant. If it starts to turn invasive, simply pull out excess rhizomes regularly.
soil: with high levels of humus, heavy
citation: “Water lily - growing it and advice on how to care for it,” Nature, 06-Sep-2018. [Online]. Available: https://www.nature-and-garden.com/gardening/water-lilies.html. [Accessed: 11-Apr-2019].

name: wild pansy
gen info:
edible flowers - used as decorations and garnishes
non-aggressive
non-invasive
not native to North America - Hybrids of plants native to Europe.
tolerates frost
how to plant:
Propagate by seed - Start seeds indoors 10 to 12 weeks before the last spring frost. Lightly cover the seeds with soil, as they need light to germinate. After sowing, slightly moisten the potting mix and place the seed tray in the refrigerator for 2 weeks, then move to heated area.

Germination temperature: 65 F to 70 F

Days to emergence: 14 to 21
watering: Deadhead to prolong bloom. Pinch to keep bushy. Keep soil moist but not soggy. Remove plants when they die back from summer heat.
warnings: Pests: Aphids Mealybug Spider mites Parasitic nematodes
soil: Prefers rich, moist but well-drained soil.
citation: "Pansy," Explore Cornell - Home Gardening - Flower Growing Guides - Growing Guide. [Online]. Available: http://www.gardening.cornell.edu/homegardening/scenede13.html. [Accessed: 11-Apr-2019].

name: windflower
gen info:
deer resistant
non-aggressive
non-invasive
not native to North America - Native to high mountainous regions in Europe.
how to plant: Propagate by division or separation - Divide the plant clumps in fall. Plants will also self-sow. Apply mulch in fall for winter protection.
soil: prefers rich, well-drained soil
citation: "Windflower," Explore Cornell - Home Gardening - Flower Growing Guides - Growing Guide. [Online]. Available: http://www.gardening.cornell.edu/homegardening/scene238d.html. [Accessed: 11-Apr-2019].

name: yellow iris
gen info: non-invasive, not native to North America, native to Europe and North America
how to plant: Propagate by seed, division or separation - Divide in the spring or fall. Often self-sows. Deadhead after flowering to prevent self sowing. Divide in the spring or fall as needed.
watering: Performs best when roots are submerged in water or at least receive constant moisture.
seasons: blooms in late spring and early summer
warnings: aggressive - Self-seeds prolifically if not deadheaded
soil:
requires damp soil
Tolerates poor drainage
citation: "Iris, Yellow Flag," Explore Cornell - Home Gardening - Flower Growing Guides - Growing Guide. [Online]. Available: http://www.gardening.cornell.edu/homegardening/scene8f3c.html. [Accessed: 11-Apr-2019].
